awd_titl_txt: Dynamics of Coupled Heterogeneous Oscillators with Application to Biological Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This study will examine the behavior that arises from the interactions of oscillating systems with fundamentally different underlying physical principles. The oscillators have different natural rates and wave shapes. The work asks how collective behavior is sensitive to changes in the oscillators and the communications between oscillators. The study of coupled nonlinear oscillators can lead to a deep understanding of biological systems. Physically dissimilar biological oscillators are of particular interest. Other biological oscillators exhibit complex waveforms, such as the spiking of neurons. Despite the prevalence of dissimilar interacting biological systems, there have been few related experiments. Most studies examine homogeneous oscillators within one system type. Students will be trained in understanding, modeling, simulating, and experimentally investigating coupled physically dissimilar systems.
 
This project will perform experiments that couple dissimilar physical oscillator systems. Through these experiments, strengths and weaknesses of reduced-variable models will be revealed that may not be apparent in systems of similar oscillators. Reduced-variable models are important to the analysis of biological oscillators, thus, insights into the models are important.  The systems to be studied have different oscillatory dynamics with analogous biological modes; like the heart, an opto-mechanical oscillator can exhibit multiple spatial modes of oscillation while the lungs and an opto-electronic oscillator cannot. Unlike biological oscillators, there are accurate mathematical models for these dissimilar oscillators. Thus, this work will create a flexible experimental proxy for interactions between dissimilar biological systems, while providing an opportunity for theoretical advancements in the study of synchronization, delayed coupling, and interacting oscillators with different physical properties.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Many biological systems contain interacting oscillators;  examples include neurons, heart cells, the menstrual cycle, the Circadian rhythm, and breathing. Often times the oscillators that are coupled are physically dissimilar from one another, as in the case of the cardiorespiratory interactions between the heart and the lungs. This proposal has focused on the important case that the oscillators that are coupled are physically dissimilar from one another.

Despite the prevalence of dissimilar interacting biological systems, there have been few related experiments. Most previous studies have examined homogeneous oscillators within one system type. This study has performed experiments that couple dissimilar physical oscillator systems, and so it has created a flexible experimental proxy for interactions between dissimilar biological systems, while providing an opportunity for theoretical advancements in the study of synchronization, delayed coupling, and interacting oscillators with different physical properties.

The team has studied both theoretically and experimentally synchronization in small networks formed of coupled physically dissimilar oscillators. The research has included: (1) an experimental investigation of physically dissimilar oscillators coupled together in one physical apparatus; (2) a theoretical approach to arrive at a full characterization of the multi-physics dynamics. 

The team has studied analytically, numerically, and experimentally the general problem of cluster synchronization (CS) in multilayer networks; these systems are composed of heterogeneous components that may interact in multiple ways. For the first time the group of symmetries of a multilayer network has been defined and it has been explained how to compute it. An analysis of several datasets of real multilayer networks shows they possess large number of symmetries. A study of stability of the CS patterns that are predicted by the theory has been performed. The symmetries of each layer as well as the particular pattern of interlayer connections determine the CS patterns in multilayer networks; it has been described how each layer’s symmetry group relates to the symmetry groups of other layers through interlayer connections. The interplay between the intralayer and interlayer couplings enables distinction between symmetries that affect the types of allowed dynamics in the other layers and those that do not. The study of stability of CS patterns has been decoupled into several simpler (lower-dimensional) problems. Each independent set of equations corresponds to the stability of either an individual cluster or a set of intertwined clusters.

In one study the team has performed experiments with a network of electronic Colpitts oscillators with two interaction layers. The appearance of several cluster states has been observed and analytically characterized as the coupling in the layers was varied. Four kinds of synchronized states have been observed, from fully synchronous to a clustered quasiperiodic state—the first experimental observation of the latter state. In another study, the team has performed experiments with a fully analog multilayer network with several electronic oscillators of three different kinds coupled with two kinds of coupling. The testbed circuits have many features that occur in natural multilayer systems, like noise and parameter mismatches. These experiments are a good test of the theoretical framework because they allow understanding how theoretical predictions, made with simplifying assumptions, can be a guide to better understand real phenomena. In fact, the experimental results largely match the theoretical predictions.

The outcomes of the proposed research have a strong potential for providing benefits to society. By constructing and studying an experimental set-up formed of physically dissimilar oscillators, the team has shed light into the coexistence and interdependence of several types of oscillations in a complex multi-physics experiment. This work has provided a flexible experimental proxy for interactions between dissimilar biological systems. Heart diseases are the leading cause of death among the US population and the world population, overall. There is scientific evidence that arrhythmia and other cardiac disorders are associated with changes in other oscillations in the body, such neuronal and circadian. It is therefore important to understand how interactions between physically dissimilar oscillators occur and what are the possible causes of dramatic changes of the dynamics. 

Beyond better understanding oscillations in biological systems, the models and systems developed during the course of this project have applications in a variety of heterogeneous oscillatory systems for industrial applications. The proposed oscillatory sensor configurations may find applications in medical, industrial and military systems.

 


Last Modified: 07/29/2022
Modified by: Francesco Sorrentino
